reasoning: Cruciality is high because the paper’s optimism about compromise/trade is explicitly fragile to ‘bads are cheap’ and threats; if digital suffering scales easily, it can dominate expected value and flip priorities toward prevention/enforcement. Paper-specificity is high: the question directly stress-tests the paper’s central mechanism (trade-based optimism) using the paper’s own digital-welfare and threat caveats (§3.2–§3.4, plus §2.2.2). Tractability is moderate: we can make partial progress via modeling (compute-cost-to-suffering vs welfare, incentive analysis for creating digital labor/agents, threat-credibility game theory, governance/contracting feasibility), but forecasting “massive scale” creation and normative ‘cheap bads’ under post-AGI conditions remains highly uncertain. Clarity is decent but bundles multiple sub-questions (scale of digital minds, prevalence of suffering vs welfare, and threat/execution dynamics), which introduces ambiguity about what constitutes an answer. Decision hook is explicit and well-posed (digital safeguards vs relying on trade). Dead weight is low: the anchor and implications mostly sharpen the question rather than restating the paper.
title: Digital welfare catastrophe vs gains from moral trade
